advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably one of the first adverts for the Osborne 1.<br> Personal Computing, February 1982.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE LOGO (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple Logo was a very successful implementation of Logo. It contained some advanced features such as property list and packages, as well as extremely good documentation.<br><br> At the time, Apple thought the Logo language would encourage schools to invest heavily in personal computers for all the class levels.<br> Sadly, Logo never became the revolutionary language that they had hoped for and very few schools taught it to their pupils (except in France).</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT SEPT. 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> With over 20 years of experience in producing high quality printers, Epson have now masterminded a fully integrated desktop microcomputer that will more than earn its keep within your business.<br> The QX-IO is capable of performing all the tasks you will ever require of it, quickly and efficiently. Installation of the QX-IO can be carried out with the minimum of interruption, and with its easily understandable keyboard, it is simplicity itself to operate. Having such a diverse range of software packages available such as database from Pearl and office productivity and accountancy from Peachtree with CP/M and multifont BASIC as standard, the QX-IO can supply all the answers whatever your business.<br> Just look at what's on offer: a big memory - 192k upgradable to 256k RAM and all the graphics you'll ever need - and high resolution graphics at that.<br> The ability to communicate easily with other machines, including our own HX-20 and the advantage of using our fine range of printers, make the QX-lO a totally versatile system at a price you'll find impossible to equal.<br> £1735 plus VAT.<br> If you're looking at micros, look at the QX-IO. The system with all the answers. </font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT, JAN. 1984</strong></font><br><blockquote>Seductive Sanco computing.<br><br> Treat you to a star for less than 3,000 Euros</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Chuck Hunkle, who worked at MSI in 1977-79, kindly sent us the complete 1978 MSI catalog. All the pages are shown in the following pictures.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT (1989)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This brochure was jointly published by Philips and American Interactive Media (the Philips/PolyGram joint venture that was set up to develop CD-i consumer software prior to the launch of the hardware). It was intented to give a general overview of CD-i's functionality in a consumer area. The brochure was presented to visitors of multimedia fairs and business partners at around 1989. The CD-i unit (including the remote control) that is displayed is an artist's impression of a player, it was never actually produced. The first consumer CD-i player, the CDI 910, appeared on the market in the US in October 1991. <br><br> <font color="#666666">Source = <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a></font><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.icdia.org/" target="_blank">The New International CD-i Association</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 36 MHZ. IN 1982?</strong></font><br><blockquote>The title of this advert was very optimistic. In fact, the 36 Mhz speed is obtained by adding the speed of the 9 x Z80 cards installed into the system. The maximum system speed was in fact 4 Mhz.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Altos emphasized its software package offer.<br><br> advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You also get the new ALTOS ACCOUNTANT, a completely integrated business accounting system...<br><br> There's more. You get the unique ALTOS COMPUTER TUTOR, the self-teaching tutorial that provides simple, self paced, step-by-step training that make using the computer easy...</font></blockquote>

computer.coprocessor: Video Display Controller (VDC): Custom Intel IC generating all audio & video
computer.description:
Siera Electronics is a manufacturer of electronic and audio equipment that was founded in the Netherlands but is now based in Belgium (source : The Odyssey? Homepage) . Siera distributed Videopac systems and games (where ? Belgium?) under its own company name.
The Siera G7000 is only a Philips Videopac G7000 rebadged with the Siera logo. Siera also released the Philips Videopac G7400 under its own brand.
Nearly nothing is known about Siera... See Videopac G7000 entry for more details.

emulator.description: This excellent Odyssey² website has a very detailed page about Videopac/Odyssey² emulation
emulator.name: Odyssey? Home Page - Emulation Ressource

emulator.description: Excellent emulator which can play Odyssey²/Videopac as well as Videopac+ games !
emulator.name: O2EM

item.description: Vocal synthesizer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> VOCAL SYNTHESIZER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract from <a href="http://www.classicgaming.com/o2home/index.asp" target="_blank">The Odyssey² Homepage</a> : <br><br> The Voice of Odyssey² was released in 1982, and allows the console to emit realistic voices and sound effects. It is silver, the same color as the console, and fits snugly into the cartridge port. Once installed, an Odyssey² with a Voice looks like a single unit, not two things hooked together. The Voice has a self-contained speaker (the voices do not come out of the television), with a volume control. Regular cartridges will play normally through the Voice unit. Voice modules are uncommon, and every Odyssey² collector wants one, making them somewhat valuable. There is no European version of The Voice. In Brazil, a Voice module was announced but never released (see below). </blockquote>
Mounted on the system||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOUNTED ON THE SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.keyboard: Two 8-directions self-centered joysticks with fire button
computer.name: G7000
